key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse, found not guilty of charges stemming from the shootings during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin, claims he's not racist and supports the BLM movement.
In an interview with Tucker Carlson set to air on Fox News, Rittenhouse says the case was about the right to self-defense, not race.
Rittenhouse, who is white, as were the men he shot, insists he supports peaceful demonstrations.
A spokesman for the Rittenhouse family, David Hancock, describes Kyle as caring, empathetic, and civic-minded.
Rittenhouse was 17 when he traveled to Kenosha, which had been rocked by protests following the shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man, by a white police officer.
During his trial, Rittenhouse argued he fired in self-defense after being attacked.
Rittenhouse has been a focal point for debates on Second Amendment rights and protests against police brutality.
Despite being photographed with members of the Proud Boys, Rittenhouse's attorneys deny he is a white supremacist.
A jury recently found Rittenhouse not guilty on all charges related to the shootings.
NAACP president and CEO Derrick Johnson views the trial result as a 'warning shot' for Black communities about 'vigilante justice.'
